newsitem.title: USA: CBOT wheat ends lower on slack demand, vomitoxin.
newsitem.headline: CBOT wheat ends lower on slack demand, vomitoxin.

text.p: A slowdown in export sales coupled with prospects for increases in the deliverable supply of wheat after a recent rejection by Egypt of U.S. soft red supplies pressured CBOT wheat futures to a lower close, traders said.
"There is still the vomitoxin talk in wheat," said Ron Kucha of O'Connor and Co.
Egypt recently rejected U.S. soft red winter wheat on concerns about vomitoxin.
Other than a "gentleman's agreement", there are no provisions to keep wheat containing vomitoxin from being posted for delivery on CBOT wheat futures contracts.
Wheat also sagged on diminished fears of frost damage.
An Environment Canada meteorologist early Wednesday said temperatures dipped overnight in the foothills of Alberta but key grain growing regions in the Canadian Prairies remained frost free.
Phil Wright of Environment Canada said it appears there was little, if any, danger of frost.
Wheat rallied early this week on concerns about potential cold weather damage to portions of the Canadian spring wheat growing region.
Wheat closed two to 4-1/4 cents per bushel lower, with September down 3-1/2 at $4.51.
Wheat futures volume was estimated at 14,000, down from 14,636 Tuesday.
In the wheat options pit volume was thin with Paine Webber a seller of December $4.50 puts and Refco Inc sold September $5.00 puts, traders said.
Wheat options volume was estimated at 4,500, up from 4,388 Tuesday.
